title: Paradise Towers
dialogue_triumphs: 'Are these old ladies annoying you?' 'No.' 'Are you annoying these old ladies?'

continuity_notes.name: Paradise Towers
continuity_notes.description: A 21st-century high-rise building designed by Kroagnon, which won many awards.
continuity_notes.current_status: Inhabited by the elderly, young, and caretakers after those of fighting age left for war.

continuity_notes.name: Kroagnon
continuity_notes.description: Also known as the Great Architect, designer of Paradise Towers and other famous structures.
continuity_notes.current_status: Brain exiled to the basement of Paradise Towers.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS Swimming Pool
continuity_notes.description: A feature of the TARDIS that was leaking and had to be jettisoned.

continuity_notes.name: Griophos
continuity_notes.description: A planet with a spectacular pool for the exclusive use of flesh-eating octopi called Gulmeri.

continuity_notes.name: Kangs
continuity_notes.description: A group in Paradise Towers, likely composed of young residents.
continuity_notes.current_status: Active in Paradise Towers; made the Doctor an honorary member.

technobabble: The Robotic Self-activating Megapodic Mark 7Z cleaners have oxymotive blades.
The Doctor describes an antique phone as a splendid piece of audioarchitectonicalmetrasynchosity.
Kroagnon 'transplants' his brain into the Chief Caretaker's body via corporal ectoscopy.
roots: Several of Tharg's Future Shocks from the 2000AD comic
The Restaurant at the End of the Universe

locations.name: Paradise Towers
locations.description: A 21st-century high-rise building designed by Kroagnon, inhabited by various groups after the war.
locations.current_status: Setting of the episode, with various factions living within.

future_history: Paradise Towers won many awards in the 21st century, suggesting advanced architectural developments.
additional_notes: The episode features semantic cleverness with phrases like 'taken to the cleaners', 'brain quarters', and 'cowardly cutlet'. The caretakers are portrayed in a way reminiscent of the Village People and Basil Fawlty.
bottom_line: A lovely basic idea, somewhat thwarted by its uncertain tone and presentation. The episode doesn't quite work despite its clever elements and mockery of rule-bound caretakers.
